frame.name: Direction
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Path</fen> made up of a set of positions in some N-space <fen>Domain</fen> (by default spatial, or metaphorically, other domains) is determined as a function of a <fen>Landmark</fen> (which may be incorporated and is usually implicit) and some one-dimensional <fen>Independent_variable</fen> (time, or, metaphorically, other domains). The <fen>Domain</fen> and/or the <fen>Independent_variable</fen> are incorporated in the basic definition of the target.
This frame is generally used to describe the motion of something along the <fen>Path</fen> from the <fen>Landmark</fen>, which is normally implicitly identified as the location of the viewpoint:
<ex>We went <t><fex name="Path">north</fex></t> . <fex name="Landmark">DNI</fex></ex> <ex>After she was knocked on the head , it seemed like everything had moved <fex name="Distance">three feet</fex> <m>to</m> the <t>left</t> . <fex name="Landmark">DNI</fex></ex>
It can often be used for direction of facing and fictive (non-actual) motion as well:
<ex>Look <t><fex name="Path">left</fex></t> and you 'll see it . <fex name="Landmark">DNI</fex> </ex>
Words in this frame are commonly used in a fictive motion pattern to identify locations that can be reached by moving in the indicated way from the <fen>Landmark</fen>:
<ex>The book was unreachable, <fex name="Distance">10 feet</fex> <t><fex name="Path">up</fex></t> on the shelf. <fex name="Landmark">DNI</fex></ex> <ex><fex name="Path"><t>East</t></fex> <fex name="Landmark">of Mt. Diablo</fex> the Sierras rise majestically above the Central Valley.</ex> <ex></ex>
In the second case, the <fen>Domain</fen> and the <fen>Independent_variable</fen> are both spatial.
<ex></ex> <ex>They decided to rerate the medication <t>downward</t> <fex name="Domain">in potency</fex> .</ex> <ex></ex>
In this case, the <fen>Domain</fen> is "potency" and the <fen>Independent_variable</fen> is, as usual, time. </def-root>

FE.name: Landmark
FE.definition: <def-root>The point of reference from which the rest of the <fen>Path</fen> is reckoned.</def-root>

FE.name: Domain
FE.definition: <def-root>The kind of space in which the set of points of the <fen>Path</fen> is defined. <ex>Let us progess a bit <t>forward</t> <fex name="Dom">in time</fex> to the Napoleonic wars.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Independent_variable
FE.definition: <def-root>The one-dimensional variable with respect to which the positions on the <fen>Path</fen> are reckoned. For normal motion, the positions on the <fen>Path</fen> are with respect to time.</def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition: <def-root>How much movement in the stated direction along the <fen>Path</fen> from the <fen>Landmark</fen> there has been.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: east.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: towards the point of the horizon where the sun rises at the equinoxes, on the right-hand side of a person facing north.

lexUnit.name: up.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: towards a higher place or position.

lexUnit.name: forward.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: in the direction that one is facing or travelling.

lexUnit.name: left.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: on or to the left side.

lexUnit.name: right.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: on or to the right side

lexUnit.name: north.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east.

lexUnit.name: south.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction towards the point of the horizon 90 deg clockwise from east.

lexUnit.name: west.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction towards the point of the horizon where the sun sets at the equinoxes, on the left-hand side of a person facing north.

lexUnit.name: east.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction towards the point of the horizon where the sun rises at the equinoxes, on the right-hand side of a person facing north.

lexUnit.name: south.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction towards the point of the horizon 90 degrees clockwise from east.

lexUnit.name: outward.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: going out or away from a place.

lexUnit.name: north.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction in which a compass needle normally points, towards the horizon on the left-hand side of a person facing east. (ex "to the north of...")

lexUnit.name: west.adv
lexUnit.definition: COD: the direction towards the point of the horizon where the sun sets at the equinoxes, on the left-hand side of a person facing north. (ex. "10 feet west of..."

lexUnit.name: true north.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: Geographic north, as opposed to magnetic north.
